text.headline: Thanksgiving in letters, 1849-1904
text.text:
Thanksgiving is a time for gathering with family, but when that's not possible, long-distance communication has to suffice. During the 19th century, that meant writing letters -- such as those featured here, drawn from the Newberry's Modern Manuscripts Collection. Written by correspondents ranging from a homesick college girl to a broke Civil War soldier to a proud new father, these tales of Thanksgivings past help to expand our collective understanding of America's social and cultural history.

media.caption: Letter, November 20, 1849. Jane Everett letters, Newberry Library

text.headline: Try to imagine, 1849
text.text:
Dear Henry,
...There are so many [at college] that it is impossible to get acquainted. Every meal the tables are set for 210 persons. It seems like quite a village all in one family. Next week is thanksgiving and many of the young ladies are going home, we shall have a vacation of four days for the accomodation of such. I cannot spend it with you but if you write me some letters, I will place the likenesses that I brought with me around me and (although so many faces will be wanting) try to imagine myself really surrounded by those I love...
Don't forget you have a sister in Mt. Holyoke nor fail to write.
Yours in haste,
Jane Everett

media.caption: Envelope, 1863. Henry Patterson and James Patterson papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: What's to be did, 1862
text.text:
Dear ones at home,
...Well this is Thanksgiving's day the 24th, had a serman or a speech to day. We've ben off duty today and nothing more- This is about the last of my paper and i'm out of money. What's to be did. We may be payd soon and may not some say we are going to st Louis, yet but no certainty of it. I beleive you had better send me a dollar or so. in your next Well I must close. Direct Springfield yet. my pen is pretty near gone up.
With my Prayers and many good wishes I remain Your affectionate Bro and son
Jas Patterson

media.caption: Envelope, 1855 Nathan Kendall and Abby J. Reed Kendall papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: All right out at once, 1869
text.text:
Dear sister Abby:
...After I'd helped eat the Thanksgiving Turkey I went up to town and had my teeth extracted! Twenty one all right out at once. I took three doses of chloroform however before the dentist got them all out. I did'nt know anything about it till it was all over. Chandler went with me and took care of me. He had his taken out a month before without taking anything. But he did'nt have so many to take out as I did. Well, we both felt a good better after it - How are your teeth? They are going to last a life time are'nt they? 'Tis quite the fashion to have false teeth here (lucky for us) most everybody wears them. We have a very superior dentist here. He makes splendid teeth! I expect I shall want to laugh all the time when I get my new ones. You know I always had miserable teeth. I guess this is enough about teeth....
Yours affectionately,
Mary

media.caption: Envelope, 1881. Jane Everett letters, Newberry Library

text.headline: It did not pay, 1870
text.text:
Dear Jennie,
...How did you spend your "Thanksgiving"? Shall I tell you how we did? Ruth's school was out for the day, and as I was not at the Office, only from ten untill two, Maria said she was going to have a nice dinner and so went to work and got it, But about noon Ma was not feeling quite as well (and you know that Annie takes all her meals in her room) we felt very lonesome and when we sat down to dinner no one had any apetite and in a minute or so she left the table without eating any thing, and Rida declared she would never cook another Holiday dinner, for that it did not pay... I hope you had a more plesant time.
I remain yours, 
Fannie L. Ellis

media.caption: Envelope, 1861. Cynthia Everett letters, Newberry Library

text.headline: Most lovely, 1870
text.text:
Dear Jennie,
...Thanksgiving day our church and the colored M.E. churches under charge of Mr. Lewis held union services at the Cemetery church of which Mr. L. is pastor. Several of the teachers went. I did not, as the walk was long and I did not feel very strong. While they were absent Mrs. G and my roommate trimmed the parlor with evergreen and flowers and hanging moss. It was most lovely... We had turkey and mince and pumpkin pies. In the evening the church and school met in the chapel. Mr. Ford and Mr. Lewis each made short addresses and we had a pleasant social time at its close...
Good night, dear sister,
Cynthia

media.caption: Letter, 1880. Edward Williams Everett letters, Newberry Library

text.headline: I can skate nicely, 1880
text.text:
Dear Aunt Sarah,
...We have just two hens now and we are going to have one for thanksgiving day. I am a going to study grammar in a little while. I can skate on the walks nicely. Emma Johnson was here yesterday and stayed half an hour. Papa has been two times over the river with a cutter, the snow is about 8 inches deep here. I am earning 2 Dollars of Papa by brushing my teeth and not picking my teeth with a pin. I guess I will close with love to all.
Jay Carroll Everett

media.caption: Envelope, 1904. John Edward Everett letters, Newberry Library

text.headline: A Thanksgiving baby, 1904
text.text:
My Dear Aunt Mary,
A little daughter was born here Thursday evening - a Thankgiving baby... Helen is apparently doing first-rate, Baby is perfect and strong, and weighs 8 pounds. It has a pretty round head and face, It has some hair, more than our other children had. Edward is very greatly pleased with his little sister, as the other children are. Edward points to himself when we ask him whose baby it is. He evidently feels he has property rights in her...
With much love, your nephew,
J.E. Everett
